abstract.text: The visual contents of the material property—a color, image, or source of animated content. Animatable.

inlineContent.text: For details on each visual property and the ways their contents affect a material’s appearance, see
You can set a value for this property using any of the following types:
), specifying a uniform color for the material’s surface
), specifying a uniform scalar value for the material’s surface (useful for physically based properties such as
), specifying a texture to be mapped across the material’s surface
object specifying the location of an image file
A specially formatted image or array of six images, specifying the faces of a cube map
When you examine elements of a scene loaded from a file, this value is always either a color object (of the
class, according to platform) or an image object (of the
class, according to platform). You can therefore use type introspection (the
matching in Swift) to determine the type of the material property’s contents.
In iOS 11, you may use an
object to preview live video from a capture device as a material property. In iOS 11, tvOS 11, and macOS 10.13, you may use an
object as a material property for video playback.

You may specify any Core Animation layer as the contents of a material property, such as a layer with an animated sublayer hierarchy. SceneKit cannot use a layer that is already being displayed elsewhere (for example, the backing layer of a
You can use the SpriteKit framework to provide static or animated content for a material property. SpriteKit provides options for generating and modifying texture images, such as the
method. You can also use an entire animated SpriteKit scene as the material property’s contents. When you use a
object as a material property’s contents, the
properties automatically update to match the corresponding features of the SpriteKit texture.
If the current content is a solid color, you can use explicit or implicit animations (see

) to change to another color, creating an effect that fades between the two colors. Using animations to change from or to other content types results in an instantaneous transition—for an animated transition between textured content types (or types that are themselves animated), create a shader modifier (see
SceneKit supports cube maps only for a material’s

property. You can provide a cube map in any of the ways described in Table 1. Of these formats, the vertical strip provides the best performance, because it matches the memory layout SceneKit uses for rendering cube textures.
(pixel x/y positions map to latitude/longitude coordinates on a sphere)

abstract.text: An object that represents a hardware or virtual capture device like a camera or microphone.
An object that provides the interface to control the player’s transport behavior.
An object that stores color data and sometimes opacity (alpha value).
A high-level interface for manipulating image data.
Information about OpenGL textures created by the [`GLKTextureLoader`](doc://com.apple.glkit/documentation/GLKit/GLKTextureLoader) class.
A resource that holds formatted image data.
A source of texel data to be used in rendering material surface appearances.
An object that manages image-based content and allows you to perform animations on that content.
An object that organizes all of the active SpriteKit content.
An image, decoded on the GPU, that can be used to render various SpriteKit objects.
Creates a normal map texture by analyzing the contents of an existing texture.
An object that stores color data and sometimes opacity.
An object that manages image data in your app.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
A set of components that define a color, with a color space specifying how to interpret them.
A bitmap image or image mask.
An object wrapper for primitive scalar numeric values.
A static, plain-text Unicode string object which you use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
An object representing the location of a resource that bridges to ; use  when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether the receiver is an instance of given class or an instance of any class that inherits from that class.
Create 3D games and add 3D content to apps using high-level scene descriptions, and easily add animations, physics simulation, particle effects, and realistic physically based rendering.
A set of shading attributes that define the appearance of a geometry’s surface when rendered.
An object that provides color values to determine how metallic the material’s surface appears.
An object that defines the reflected color for each point on a surface.
A container for the color or texture of one of a material’s visual properties.
The visual contents of the material property—a color, image, or source of animated content. Animatable.
The transformation applied to the material property’s visual contents. Animatable.
A number between
and
that modulates the effect of the material property. Animatable.
Texture filtering for rendering the material property’s image contents at a size larger than that of the original image.
Texture filtering for rendering the material property’s image contents at a size smaller than that of the original image.
Texture filtering for using mipmaps to render the material property’s image contents at a size smaller than that of the original image.
The wrapping behavior for the S texture coordinate.
The wrapping behavior for the T texture coordinate.
A background to be rendered before the rest of the scene.
A cube map texture that depicts the environment surrounding the scene’s contents, used for advanced lighting effects.
Methods for customizing SceneKit’s rendering of geometry and materials using Metal or OpenGL shader programs.
Learn about implicit animations, explicit animations, and actions, and when to choose each in your app.

value.text: An object that represents the location of a resource, such as an item on a remote server or the path to a local file.
A static, plain-text Unicode string object.
